Vet this policy shows no lack of spirit; nor does it indicate that the members of the
classes did not want to break up the banquets. It does show, however, that the classes took a
sensible view of the matter, and stuck to it. In the first place, rough-house places the college
man in an awkward position before the public. It makes him appear too elementary; and the
disturbance he creates incurs the disgust of the people for the college permitting it. In the
second place, it is never an advisable policy for students to act in direct opposition to the
general attitude of the faculty. Therefore, the heads of the respective classes, who, by their
good judgment in outlining the course for their classes, prevented a repetition of last year's
trouble, and set a new standard for the future, deserve to be congratulated.

SPRING.
Spring has come upon us;
Our campus is free from ice.
The boys are pitching nickles,
Instead of throwing dice.
The cage is now deserted;
The haven is Homewood field;
For to training in athletics
All other pleasures yield.
Those who do not play lacrosse,
But excel in other sports
Can find 'way out at Homewood.
Fine cinder tennis-courts.
The shrine of Bacchus still remains
Wits its cooling drinks galore.
Its keeps its crowd of worshippers
Who order cock-tails, more and more.
The halls are all forsaken
But only one you'll find; —
Upstairs in the library,
The lonely, lonely grind.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

THE AWAKENING OF ELLIOTT ROWE.
The dance was at its height, nearly every
one had picked out his especial "strike" for
the evening, and the cozy corners and stairs
were already working overtime, when Lillian
Parker arrived.
It was her way of doing things. She knew
she was beautiful and attractive, and that her
presence was an added charm to any gathering. Consequently, she always timed her
arrival so that it would have the greatest effect.
Men adored her, and, naturally, every girl
who had succeeded in making an impression
felt a little uncertain as to how long she would
be in the ascendency with this new star on
the horizon. Their trepidation was shortlived, however, for apparently the new arrival
had eyes for no one in the room. Everybody
she saw was an old story to her. She had
held captive, at one time or another, every
'desirable' there. Her partner for the evening was her brother, and when she discovered
that there were no new conquests to be made,
she turned to him impatiently because she had
allowed him to influence her to attend.
As she ascended the stairs, however, her
eye fell on a new face, a young, handsome,
wholesome face, but a very innocent one, and
its look of utter guilelessness interested her.
The boy it belonged to rose as she went by,
and glanced at her from clear eyes of blue.
Her own black eyes answered him with a
challenge, which, although he did not understand it, made him blush. That decided the
matter for Miss Parker.
She didn't know, of course, that this youth
she had just seen was engaged to be married,
that he was supposed to be desperately in love
with the girl sitting beside him on the stairs,
whom she had hardly noticed; but such was
the case.
They were as common-place a couple as one
could well find. Elliott Rowe was a youth of
about twenty-two, not clever by any means,
but with a pleasing manner that endeared him
to the hearts of old ladies. He had been
brought up in the country by his mother, a
well-to-do widow, and his education had been
entirely at home. It was only when increasing years had made it advisable for him to
seek some occupation that his mother had
allowed him to come to the city to enter the

business formerly conducted by his father.
He was, in short, a very ordinary boy, goodhearted and wholesome, and by reason of his
early training, the slightest bit effeminate.
He had not had much experience with the
world, and the even tenor of his life had never
been disturbed by any great emotion.
Anna Martin, the girl, was in some ways,
much like him. She too, had never felt anything very keenly, but her state was the result
of inability to comprehend rather than lack of
experience. All her life, her mother had
pushed her forward, had attempted to make
her an accomplished woman, and Anna had
taken it all in perfect good humor, and had
tried to fulfill her mother's wishes. She said
all the little conversational polite phrases that
that estimable lady had taught her; when a
good story was told she laughed when everybody else laughed, but had no knowledge of
why she laughed. After two seasons out, life
was still an incomprehensible book to her.
Although, because her mother desired it, she
was willing to mix in the social world, she
would have been just as well content to sit at
home and fold her hands. It really made no
difference to her one way or the other.
Her pretty face, and simple, confiding manner struck Elliott at their first meeting. He,
too, had failed to grasp as yet the significance
of the world into which he had been suddenly
thrust, and this young girl, with her pretty
face and attractive clothes, who did not try to
turn his every word into a compliment, nor
make confusing witty replies to his commonplace remarks, pleased him mightily, and he
went out of his way to make himself attractive to her.
The inevitable happened. I don't pretend
to know whether or not Anna was really in
love. I rather believe she was not capable of
the sublime passion. But it is certain that
after a few months they were together constantly. It used to amuse their friends to
wonder what they talked about, because two
such unawakened persons were probably never
before thrown together. Their tastes were
not diverse—they simply had no tastes.
Whether, under the warming influence of
Elliott's personali6r, an unsuspected seed of
love did sprout and grow into a tiny plant in
Anna's heart, I am unable to say. I am in-

THE7NEWS-LETTER.

clined to think, however, that the fine hand
of Mrs. Martin was discernible in the announcement of their engagement, which came
after they had known each other about six
months.
Elliott took his good fortune as the most
natural thing in the world. He knew that it
was the custom for young men to marry, and
he felt that he was doing quite the correct
thing. Anna was not affected in the least.
She received the good wishes of her friends
with the meaningless smile that had come to
be habitual with her. It was only when she
glanced at Elliott that it became possibly a
little less like the smile of a sleeping child,
and showed something of the joy of woman's
love. Now they were to be married in two
months, and if they thought about it all, both
imagined themselves very happy and fortunate.
When Lillian came down the stairs again to
the room where the dancing was going on,
she spoke to her hostess of Elliott, and that
lady, who, like every one else, had fallen
under the charms of the girl's personality
sought out the callow youth, and presented
him, blushing mightily from his remembrance
of the encounter on the stair.
Lillian received him graciously, however,
and before he knew it he had asked her for
the next dance, quite forgetful of the fact that
Anna was still sitting up on the stair waiting
for his return.
The sensuousness of that waltz intoxicated
him. Never before had he danced with a
woman who yielded herself so completely to
his control. When, at its conclusion, he led
her to a secluded spot beneath the stairs, and
was seated by her side, he was sure he had
never seen anyone quite so beautiful. This
creature of whom he had often heard, and
whom he had somehow or other always considered as occupying a height somewhere
above him, was seated here at his side. But
she was not a grand lady, but a delightful,
girlish creature, with a color that came and
went, and soft luminous eyes, and the sweetest, most sympathetic of mouths. He was
emboldened to essay a compliment, which
she turned aside lightly, and answered in
kind. Before he was aware of it, he was
growing confidential. He told of hopes and
ambitions that an hour before he had not

5

known were existent. She lent a sympathetic
ear to all he said, showed an appreciation of
his merits, and placed his confessed weaknesses in a light that made them appear
virtues.
Meanwhile little Anna was sitting alone on
the stairs, waiting.
When, after Lillian had dismissed him with
the promise of another dance before the evening was over, remembrance came to him, and
he sought out his fiancee, she received him
jpyfully. There was not a word of reproach
for his long desertion. The significance of it
had, of course, not dawned upon her. Together they sat upon the stairs, as they had
before. She was just as happy as ever. His
mind, however, was in a turmoil. Now and
then he would catch a glimpse of the wonderful girl he had just left, as she whirled around
over the polished floor, and he could not help
making mental comparisons. And in these
comparisons Anna always suffered. She
seemed so insignificant. He remembered with
a pang that she had never given him a compliment. He felt like a man who, after gaining his knowledge of flowers from violets, had
just seen a full-blown crimson rose. He
waited for his promised dance with a feverishness that made him pay little outward attention to the girl beside him. He observed with
alarm that her eyes were blank and expressionless, and he felt an antagonism against
her rising in his breast. He saw how she
must appear to the rest of the world. A disgust with himself welled up in him that he
had been so deceived. When, at last, the
promised dance came he left Anna with
hardly a word, and hurried to his new-found
deity. Another talk in the solitude of the
seat beneath the stair, and he felt an added
repugnance when he returned to Anna to take
her home. She, poor girl, if she saw aught
unusual in her recalcitrant lover's conduct,
betrayed no sign, and their ride home was an
uneventful one from her point of view. She
probably spent the night in unbroken slumber.
Not so Elliott. He hardly closed his eyes
at all, When he did, it was to dream fitful
dreams that soon brought him out of his
sleep. The next day and the next he found
some excuse for not going near his betrothed.
On the next he happened to meet the cause of

6

THE NEWS-LETTER.

all the trouble, as he came home from his
office in the evening. They walked together
until it was quite dark. He confessed his engagement, which she probably knew by this
time, told her of the awful mistake he had
made, and requested and received an invitation to call.
It is unnecessary to trace every step of the
way. His engagement with Anna Martin
was broken off before two weeks were over.
The poor girl has probably not realized to this
day just what was the trouble.
But Elliott realized before many weeks
were over that he, too, like the many, was
but a pastime for Miss Parker. It affected
him quite deeply at first, but his newly
awakened knowledge of the world came to
his aid, and Ile soon became reconciled to
seeing Miss Parker proceed in her cause of
heart-breaking.

THE HISTORY OF LACROSSE AT
JOHNS HOPKINS.
By WILLIAm C. SCHMEISSER.

16th—Johns Hopkins, 1; Lehigh University, 10.

November 10, 1908.

The lacrosse interest was practically extinct
at the university owing to the fact that the
team of 1896 had made a poor showing, but
two things occured which again fanned on the
lacrosse spark that was left, into a bright
flame.

(Continued).
1896.
When we reach the team of 1896 the
authorities leave its nothing but some bare
facts as to the personnel of the Johns Hopkins
Lacrosse Team and the scores of the games
played, all of which are given below. After
the Hullabaloo of 1897 had buried this team
in a cold grave of facts, the Hullabaloo of
1898 adds this epitaph, ''our 1896 team made
such a poor showing against Lehigh, being
defeated 10 to 1, that all lovers of the game
at Hopkins became disgusted.

1897.

One of these thing, was that William Harvey
Maddren, one of the members of the Crescent
Athletic Club Team, came to Hopkins to
study. He was full of enthusiasm for the
game and at the same time had ability and
experience ill organizing and coaching lacrosse
men. The other favorable circumstance was
that the university did not maintain a football
team in the fall of 1896, and the men had no
athletic work with which to fill in their
recreation hours.
Maddren was elected captain and immediately set to work in his characteristic way
to boom lacrosse. A call for candidates was
made as early as the middle of October and in
addition to the three men who were left over
from the preceding season a large number of
promising men responded, most of whom were
very lightly burdened with lacrosse knowledge. A mass meeting was then held and
after many speeches, it was decided that
everybody would put his shoulders to the
wheel and push for another good lacrosse
team.

8

THE NEWS-LETTER.

Every day the candidates were put through
a course of tipping and throwing in the yard,
which has since been made the resting place
of our beautiful cage, and which then adjoined
the old gymnasium with its stove around
which stories were swapped which are now
taken care of in our more commodious trophy
room.
Three steps in the development of this
team must be mentioned, as it showed with
what determination the men worked: First,
no man was allowed to play on the team who
did not do a certain amount of 'gym" work.
Secondly, on Saturdays, the men went out
to Druid Hill Park and scrub games were
played. Thirdly, on about February first,
the men were put on a training diet which
was adhered to throughout the season.
Our '97 team had more practice games than
any Hopkins lacrosse team ever had had up
to that time. This was of great benefit to
the green men, who would most certainly
have lost their heads in the. championship
contests, but for this previous experience.
Our boys made a victorious record until the
Lehigh game, when history in substance
reports that being a new team they were
somewhat afflicted with over-confidence. The
game itself was one of the prettiest and evenlymatched contests that has ever been played.
Lehigh excelled in tipping and catching,
whereas our boys were better runners and
were better trained. Lehigh won by a score
of 6-3 and we did not get the championship.
The team finished the season in Brooklyn
by playing a game with the Crescent Athletic
Club Team in which they learned a great deal,
but were defeated by a score of 5-2.
Thus ended the most prosperous season our
lacrosse men had since 1891, when we won
our first Intercollegiate Championship of the
United States.
Attention must be called to the fact that it
was this year under the direction of ''Billy"
Maddren and '`Jack" Curry of the Crescent
Athletic Club Team, who came down a few
days from New York City to give our men
some points, that the Hopkins system received
its inception. Curry said; —Take the ball
down the middle of the field that is the
shortest way," and from this beginning

developed the Hopkins ''criss-cross" and its
later modifications.
The team of 1896 was composed of the
following pleyers:
C. M. Guggenheimer, goal; William H.
Maddren, point; F. A. Lupton, cover point;
William L. Hodges, first defense; T. A.
Kennard, second defense; F. W. Smith, third
defense; H. M. Wilson, centre; T. Fitzgerald,
Jr., third attack; G. C. Robinson, second
attaek; W. E. Straus, first attack; F. J.
Clunet, out home; L. A. Naylor, in home.
Substitutes—G. W. Knapp, E. Armstrong.
William H. Maddren, captain; Stephen P.
Harwood, manager.
1898.
On studying the year book for the year
1899 on the subject of lacrosse, I find that
the writer of the article in that annual was so
overjoyed and carried away by the fact that
Hopkins had won another championship after
a wait of seven years, that he burst forth in a
poetic effort, the last verse of which, and that
only, will I take the liberty to inflict on the
patient reader. It reads:
"And that old banner of Ninety-one,
Which lonely in our gym has hung,
At last has found its sequel, mate,
In the championship banner of Ninety-eight."

After this he breaks into a flowing stream
covering an entire page, which may be summed up as follows: ``The championship is
due to the consistent hard work and ability of
William H. Maddren."
How the different men played, and what
technical improvement was to be seen in the
work of the team as a whole and if any, what
new methods were employed is not set forth
in the above-mentioned Hullabaloo, so the
best the writer can do is to give you a few
general facts which have been handed down
by word of mouth.
It is interesting to note that it was in this
year that R. T. Abercrombie and Toni Fitzgerald first began to work in. Details of their
career will be taken up later.
It was also this year that Charles R. McInnes, who after playing a great game of hockey
as Rover for the University, was induced by
Maddren and Abercrombie to take up lacrosse.
He had fooled around on the lots a bit in
Canada when he was a boy, but then only as

9

THE NEWS-LETrER.

a close defense man. It was not until the
end of the season of 1898 that he first sprung
into prominence as a close attack man.
Some of the younger men who have been
in the trophy room may have seen two small
pennants with the name "Crescents" on
them, hanging on the wall and wondered
why these. They were presented to our team
of 1898 by the "Crescent" men because we
had won the championship.
Another point of historical interest is the
fact that this was the first year that the
athletic authorities decided that the lacrosse
men must win the championship of the lacrosse
league to get the letter H and not only be
awarded the same on a general showing.
The team of 1898 lined up as follows:
C. M. Guggenheimer, goal; William H.
Maddren, point; F. A. Lupton, cover point;
W. L. Hodges, first defense; J. A. Kennard,
second defense; L. W. Haskell, third defense;
R. T. Abercrombie, centre; T. Fitzgerald, Jr.,
third attack; G. C. Robinson, second attack;
G. W. Knapp, Jr., first attack; F. J. Clunet,
out home; C. R, McInnes, ill home.
George Canby Robinson, captain; Robert
Harold Grimes, manager.

THE RICHMOND MEET.
Our men showed up well in the Richmond
College Meet, February 27th, considering the
number of men entered. They won the relay
event from Western Maryland; came first in
the mile run, and scored third in the 50-yard
finals and 880-yard run.
Our relay team entered the race with Western Maryland with some trepedition, owing to
the splendid time that they showed at the
Federal Meet.
Bridgman., however, made
us feel at ease; for, following his custom
he started out ahead of his opponent, and
finished three yards to the good. Hunter held
his own, finishing a yard in front of his man,
and Fulton and Stollenwerck increased this
lead by several yards.
Dutch Breyer showed the Virginians what
sort of distance men Hopkins turns out, He

THE GEORGETOWN MEET.
Our mile relay team scored one of its greatest triumphs of the season last Saturday, when
it defeated the crack Carlisle Indian four in
one of the big events of the Georgetown Meet.
The Black and Blue four have certainly shown
wonderful speed this season, and this victory
comes as a climax in the series of victories.
Before the race began everyone seemed to
think that the Indians would run away from
the Hopkins team, but just as soon as the first
men got off it was evident that the latter was
the best team. Bridgman started out strong,
led the way all the time, and came in five
yards ahead of his man. Then Hunter started
out with Black Heart, the fastest of the Indian
team, as his opponent. Hunter ran well, but
he finished just a yard behind. Stollenwerck,
our third man, passed his opponent, Two
Heart, at the start, and running right away
from him came in with a twenty yard lead.
Fulton, the last man, took it easy all the way
and gained five yards more on Moses Friday,
the last Indian. The time of the race was

THE FEDERAL MEET.
Our mile relay team started its winning
strek at the Federal Meet, February 20th, by
defeating easily the quartet of the George
Washington University.
Our first man,
Bridgman, started well, but unfortunately
Hunter, who ran second, fell on his last lap
and lost 20 yards. Fulton ran pluckily, and
recovering the lost ground, added a slight
lead. Stollenwerck, the last man, held the
lead, winning from Smithson by 20 yards.
In the 3,000 meter run ``Dutch" Breyer ran
away from the field and won by about 65
yards. J. T. Levering, of Pennsylvania,
came second. H. Burgan took third place in
the 800-meter novice, and Jack Fulton captured third in the 600-open. The summaries:
1,500-Meter Relay—Won by Johns Hopkins, (Bridgman, Hunter, Fulton, Stollenwerck,); second, George Washington. Time,
3 minutes, 30 3-5 seconds.

SPRING.
Spring has come upon us;
Our campus is free from ice.
The boys are pitching nickles,
Instead of throwing dice.
The cage is now deserted;
The haven is Homewood field;
For to training in athletics
All other pleasures yield.
Those who do not play lacrosse,
But excel in other sports
Can find 'way out at Homewood.
Fine cinder tennis-courts.
The shrine of Bacchus still remains
Wits its cooling drinks galore.
Its keeps its crowd of worshippers
Who order cock-tails, more and more.
The halls are all forsaken
But only one you'll find; —
Upstairs in the library,
The lonely, lonely grind.

THE AWAKENING OF ELLIOTT ROWE.
The dance was at its height, nearly every
one had picked out his especial "strike" for
the evening, and the cozy corners and stairs
were already working overtime, when Lillian
Parker arrived.
It was her way of doing things. She knew
she was beautiful and attractive, and that her
presence was an added charm to any gathering. Consequently, she always timed her
arrival so that it would have the greatest effect.
Men adored her, and, naturally, every girl
who had succeeded in making an impression
felt a little uncertain as to how long she would
be in the ascendency with this new star on
the horizon. Their trepidation was shortlived, however, for apparently the new arrival
had eyes for no one in the room. Everybody
she saw was an old story to her. She had
held captive, at one time or another, every
'desirable' there. Her partner for the evening was her brother, and when she discovered
that there were no new conquests to be made,
she turned to him impatiently because she had
allowed him to influence her to attend.
As she ascended the stairs, however, her
eye fell on a new face, a young, handsome,
wholesome face, but a very innocent one, and
its look of utter guilelessness interested her.
The boy it belonged to rose as she went by,
and glanced at her from clear eyes of blue.
Her own black eyes answered him with a
challenge, which, although he did not understand it, made him blush. That decided the
matter for Miss Parker.
She didn't know, of course, that this youth
she had just seen was engaged to be married,
that he was supposed to be desperately in love
with the girl sitting beside him on the stairs,
whom she had hardly noticed; but such was
the case.
They were as common-place a couple as one
could well find. Elliott Rowe was a youth of
about twenty-two, not clever by any means,
but with a pleasing manner that endeared him
to the hearts of old ladies. He had been
brought up in the country by his mother, a
well-to-do widow, and his education had been
entirely at home. It was only when increasing years had made it advisable for him to
seek some occupation that his mother had
allowed him to come to the city to enter the

business formerly conducted by his father.
He was, in short, a very ordinary boy, goodhearted and wholesome, and by reason of his
early training, the slightest bit effeminate.
He had not had much experience with the
world, and the even tenor of his life had never
been disturbed by any great emotion.
Anna Martin, the girl, was in some ways,
much like him. She too, had never felt anything very keenly, but her state was the result
of inability to comprehend rather than lack of
experience. All her life, her mother had
pushed her forward, had attempted to make
her an accomplished woman, and Anna had
taken it all in perfect good humor, and had
tried to fulfill her mother's wishes. She said
all the little conversational polite phrases that
that estimable lady had taught her; when a
good story was told she laughed when everybody else laughed, but had no knowledge of
why she laughed. After two seasons out, life
was still an incomprehensible book to her.
Although, because her mother desired it, she
was willing to mix in the social world, she
would have been just as well content to sit at
home and fold her hands. It really made no
difference to her one way or the other.
Her pretty face, and simple, confiding manner struck Elliott at their first meeting. He,
too, had failed to grasp as yet the significance
of the world into which he had been suddenly
thrust, and this young girl, with her pretty
face and attractive clothes, who did not try to
turn his every word into a compliment, nor
make confusing witty replies to his commonplace remarks, pleased him mightily, and he
went out of his way to make himself attractive to her.
The inevitable happened. I don't pretend
to know whether or not Anna was really in
love. I rather believe she was not capable of
the sublime passion. But it is certain that
after a few months they were together constantly. It used to amuse their friends to
wonder what they talked about, because two
such unawakened persons were probably never
before thrown together. Their tastes were
not diverse—they simply had no tastes.
Whether, under the warming influence of
Elliott's personali6r, an unsuspected seed of
love did sprout and grow into a tiny plant in
Anna's heart, I am unable to say. I am in-

THE7NEWS-LETTER.

clined to think, however, that the fine hand
of Mrs. Martin was discernible in the announcement of their engagement, which came
after they had known each other about six
months.
Elliott took his good fortune as the most
natural thing in the world. He knew that it
was the custom for young men to marry, and
he felt that he was doing quite the correct
thing. Anna was not affected in the least.
She received the good wishes of her friends
with the meaningless smile that had come to
be habitual with her. It was only when she
glanced at Elliott that it became possibly a
little less like the smile of a sleeping child,
and showed something of the joy of woman's
love. Now they were to be married in two
months, and if they thought about it all, both
imagined themselves very happy and fortunate.
When Lillian came down the stairs again to
the room where the dancing was going on,
she spoke to her hostess of Elliott, and that
lady, who, like every one else, had fallen
under the charms of the girl's personality
sought out the callow youth, and presented
him, blushing mightily from his remembrance
of the encounter on the stair.
Lillian received him graciously, however,
and before he knew it he had asked her for
the next dance, quite forgetful of the fact that
Anna was still sitting up on the stair waiting
for his return.
The sensuousness of that waltz intoxicated
him. Never before had he danced with a
woman who yielded herself so completely to
his control. When, at its conclusion, he led
her to a secluded spot beneath the stairs, and
was seated by her side, he was sure he had
never seen anyone quite so beautiful. This
creature of whom he had often heard, and
whom he had somehow or other always considered as occupying a height somewhere
above him, was seated here at his side. But
she was not a grand lady, but a delightful,
girlish creature, with a color that came and
went, and soft luminous eyes, and the sweetest, most sympathetic of mouths. He was
emboldened to essay a compliment, which
she turned aside lightly, and answered in
kind. Before he was aware of it, he was
growing confidential. He told of hopes and
ambitions that an hour before he had not

5

known were existent. She lent a sympathetic
ear to all he said, showed an appreciation of
his merits, and placed his confessed weaknesses in a light that made them appear
virtues.
Meanwhile little Anna was sitting alone on
the stairs, waiting.
When, after Lillian had dismissed him with
the promise of another dance before the evening was over, remembrance came to him, and
he sought out his fiancee, she received him
jpyfully. There was not a word of reproach
for his long desertion. The significance of it
had, of course, not dawned upon her. Together they sat upon the stairs, as they had
before. She was just as happy as ever. His
mind, however, was in a turmoil. Now and
then he would catch a glimpse of the wonderful girl he had just left, as she whirled around
over the polished floor, and he could not help
making mental comparisons. And in these
comparisons Anna always suffered. She
seemed so insignificant. He remembered with
a pang that she had never given him a compliment. He felt like a man who, after gaining his knowledge of flowers from violets, had
just seen a full-blown crimson rose. He
waited for his promised dance with a feverishness that made him pay little outward attention to the girl beside him. He observed with
alarm that her eyes were blank and expressionless, and he felt an antagonism against
her rising in his breast. He saw how she
must appear to the rest of the world. A disgust with himself welled up in him that he
had been so deceived. When, at last, the
promised dance came he left Anna with
hardly a word, and hurried to his new-found
deity. Another talk in the solitude of the
seat beneath the stair, and he felt an added
repugnance when he returned to Anna to take
her home. She, poor girl, if she saw aught
unusual in her recalcitrant lover's conduct,
betrayed no sign, and their ride home was an
uneventful one from her point of view. She
probably spent the night in unbroken slumber.
Not so Elliott. He hardly closed his eyes
at all, When he did, it was to dream fitful
dreams that soon brought him out of his
sleep. The next day and the next he found
some excuse for not going near his betrothed.
On the next he happened to meet the cause of

all the trouble, as he came home from his
office in the evening. They walked together
until it was quite dark. He confessed his engagement, which she probably knew by this
time, told her of the awful mistake he had
made, and requested and received an invitation to call.
It is unnecessary to trace every step of the
way. His engagement with Anna Martin
was broken off before two weeks were over.
The poor girl has probably not realized to this
day just what was the trouble.
But Elliott realized before many weeks
were over that he, too, like the many, was
but a pastime for Miss Parker. It affected
him quite deeply at first, but his newly
awakened knowledge of the world came to
his aid, and Ile soon became reconciled to
seeing Miss Parker proceed in her cause of
heart-breaking.

November 10, 1908.

The lacrosse interest was practically extinct
at the university owing to the fact that the
team of 1896 had made a poor showing, but
two things occured which again fanned on the
lacrosse spark that was left, into a bright
flame.

1897.

One of these thing, was that William Harvey
Maddren, one of the members of the Crescent
Athletic Club Team, came to Hopkins to
study. He was full of enthusiasm for the
game and at the same time had ability and
experience ill organizing and coaching lacrosse
men. The other favorable circumstance was
that the university did not maintain a football
team in the fall of 1896, and the men had no
athletic work with which to fill in their
recreation hours.
Maddren was elected captain and immediately set to work in his characteristic way
to boom lacrosse. A call for candidates was
made as early as the middle of October and in
addition to the three men who were left over
from the preceding season a large number of
promising men responded, most of whom were
very lightly burdened with lacrosse knowledge. A mass meeting was then held and
after many speeches, it was decided that
everybody would put his shoulders to the
wheel and push for another good lacrosse
team.

8

THE NEWS-LETTER.

Every day the candidates were put through
a course of tipping and throwing in the yard,
which has since been made the resting place
of our beautiful cage, and which then adjoined
the old gymnasium with its stove around
which stories were swapped which are now
taken care of in our more commodious trophy
room.
Three steps in the development of this
team must be mentioned, as it showed with
what determination the men worked: First,
no man was allowed to play on the team who
did not do a certain amount of 'gym" work.
Secondly, on Saturdays, the men went out
to Druid Hill Park and scrub games were
played. Thirdly, on about February first,
the men were put on a training diet which
was adhered to throughout the season.
Our '97 team had more practice games than
any Hopkins lacrosse team ever had had up
to that time. This was of great benefit to
the green men, who would most certainly
have lost their heads in the. championship
contests, but for this previous experience.
Our boys made a victorious record until the
Lehigh game, when history in substance
reports that being a new team they were
somewhat afflicted with over-confidence. The
game itself was one of the prettiest and evenlymatched contests that has ever been played.
Lehigh excelled in tipping and catching,
whereas our boys were better runners and
were better trained. Lehigh won by a score
of 6-3 and we did not get the championship.
The team finished the season in Brooklyn
by playing a game with the Crescent Athletic
Club Team in which they learned a great deal,
but were defeated by a score of 5-2.
Thus ended the most prosperous season our
lacrosse men had since 1891, when we won
our first Intercollegiate Championship of the
United States.
Attention must be called to the fact that it
was this year under the direction of ''Billy"
Maddren and '`Jack" Curry of the Crescent
Athletic Club Team, who came down a few
days from New York City to give our men
some points, that the Hopkins system received
its inception. Curry said; —Take the ball
down the middle of the field that is the
shortest way," and from this beginning

developed the Hopkins ''criss-cross" and its
later modifications.
The team of 1896 was composed of the
following pleyers:
C. M. Guggenheimer, goal; William H.
Maddren, point; F. A. Lupton, cover point;
William L. Hodges, first defense; T. A.
Kennard, second defense; F. W. Smith, third
defense; H. M. Wilson, centre; T. Fitzgerald,
Jr., third attack; G. C. Robinson, second
attaek; W. E. Straus, first attack; F. J.
Clunet, out home; L. A. Naylor, in home.
Substitutes—G. W. Knapp, E. Armstrong.
William H. Maddren, captain; Stephen P.
Harwood, manager.
1898.
On studying the year book for the year
1899 on the subject of lacrosse, I find that
the writer of the article in that annual was so
overjoyed and carried away by the fact that
Hopkins had won another championship after
a wait of seven years, that he burst forth in a
poetic effort, the last verse of which, and that
only, will I take the liberty to inflict on the
patient reader. It reads:
"And that old banner of Ninety-one,
Which lonely in our gym has hung,
At last has found its sequel, mate,
In the championship banner of Ninety-eight."

After this he breaks into a flowing stream
covering an entire page, which may be summed up as follows: ``The championship is
due to the consistent hard work and ability of
William H. Maddren."
How the different men played, and what
technical improvement was to be seen in the
work of the team as a whole and if any, what
new methods were employed is not set forth
in the above-mentioned Hullabaloo, so the
best the writer can do is to give you a few
general facts which have been handed down
by word of mouth.
It is interesting to note that it was in this
year that R. T. Abercrombie and Toni Fitzgerald first began to work in. Details of their
career will be taken up later.
It was also this year that Charles R. McInnes, who after playing a great game of hockey
as Rover for the University, was induced by
Maddren and Abercrombie to take up lacrosse.
He had fooled around on the lots a bit in
Canada when he was a boy, but then only as

9

THE NEWS-LETrER.

a close defense man. It was not until the
end of the season of 1898 that he first sprung
into prominence as a close attack man.
Some of the younger men who have been
in the trophy room may have seen two small
pennants with the name "Crescents" on
them, hanging on the wall and wondered
why these. They were presented to our team
of 1898 by the "Crescent" men because we
had won the championship.
Another point of historical interest is the
fact that this was the first year that the
athletic authorities decided that the lacrosse
men must win the championship of the lacrosse
league to get the letter H and not only be
awarded the same on a general showing.
The team of 1898 lined up as follows:

THE RICHMOND MEET.
Our men showed up well in the Richmond
College Meet, February 27th, considering the
number of men entered. They won the relay
event from Western Maryland; came first in
the mile run, and scored third in the 50-yard
finals and 880-yard run.
Our relay team entered the race with Western Maryland with some trepedition, owing to
the splendid time that they showed at the
Federal Meet.
Bridgman., however, made
us feel at ease; for, following his custom
he started out ahead of his opponent, and
finished three yards to the good. Hunter held
his own, finishing a yard in front of his man,
and Fulton and Stollenwerck increased this
lead by several yards.
Dutch Breyer showed the Virginians what
sort of distance men Hopkins turns out, He

THE GEORGETOWN MEET.
Our mile relay team scored one of its greatest triumphs of the season last Saturday, when
it defeated the crack Carlisle Indian four in
one of the big events of the Georgetown Meet.
The Black and Blue four have certainly shown
wonderful speed this season, and this victory
comes as a climax in the series of victories.
Before the race began everyone seemed to
think that the Indians would run away from
the Hopkins team, but just as soon as the first
men got off it was evident that the latter was
the best team. Bridgman started out strong,
led the way all the time, and came in five
yards ahead of his man. Then Hunter started

THE FEDERAL MEET.
Our mile relay team started its winning
strek at the Federal Meet, February 20th, by
defeating easily the quartet of the George
Washington University.
Our first man,
Bridgman, started well, but unfortunately
Hunter, who ran second, fell on his last lap
and lost 20 yards. Fulton ran pluckily, and
recovering the lost ground, added a slight
lead. Stollenwerck, the last man, held the
lead, winning from Smithson by 20 yards.
In the 3,000 meter run ``Dutch" Breyer ran
away from the field and won by about 65
yards. J. T. Levering, of Pennsylvania,
came second. H. Burgan took third place in
the 800-meter novice, and Jack Fulton captured third in the 600-open. The summaries:
1,500-Meter Relay—Won by Johns Hopkins, (Bridgman, Hunter, Fulton, Stollenwerck,); second, George Washington. Time,
3 minutes, 30 3-5 seconds.
